titleInfo.title: RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE

extension.searchTitle: RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.result: So the motion to table was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Representative Sanchez rose to a question of the privileges of the House and submitted a resolution. The Chair ruled that the resolution did not present a question of the privileges of the House. Subsequently, Representative Sanchez appealed the ruling of the chair and Representative Buck moved to table the appeal. Agreed to the motion to table the appeal of the ruling of the Chair by a yea-and-nay vote of 225 yeas to 187 nays with one answering ``present'', Roll No. 274.

titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1973, PROTECTING YOUNG VICTIMS FROM SEXUAL ABUSE ACT OF 2017; PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1761, PROTECTING AGAINST CHILD EXPLOITATION ACT OF 2017; AND...

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1973, PROTECTING YOUNG VICTIMS FROM SEXUAL ABUSE ACT OF 2017; PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1761, PROTECTING AGAINST CHILD EXPLOITATION ACT OF 2017; AND...; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse Act of 2017 and Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017_Rule for Consideration
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Res. 352, providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1973) to prevent the sexual abuse of minors and amateur athletes by requiring the prompt reporting of sexual abuse to law enforcement authorities; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1761) to amend title 18, United States Code, to criminalize the knowing consent of the visual depiction, or live transmission, of a minor engaged in sexually explicit conduct, by a yea-and-nay vote of 239 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 276, �D579�after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 188 nays, Roll No. 275.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse Act of 2017 and Protecting Against Child Exploitation Act of 2017_Rule for Consideration
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Res. 352, providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1973) to prevent the sexual abuse of minors and amateur athletes by requiring the prompt reporting of sexual abuse to law enforcement authorities; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1761) to amend title 18, United States Code, to criminalize the knowing consent of the visual depiction, or live transmission, of a minor engaged in sexually explicit conduct, by a yea-and-nay vote of 239 yeas to 179 nays, Roll No. 276, �D579�after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 188 nays, Roll No. 275.

titleInfo.title: PROTECTING THE RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS AGAINST TECHNOLOGICAL EXPLOITATION ACT

extension.searchTitle: PROTECTING THE RIGHTS OF INDIVIDUALS AGAINST TECHNOLOGICAL EXPLOITATION ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the bill was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Protecting the Rights of Individuals Against Technological Exploitation Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measures. Consideration began Tuesday, May 23rd.<P/>H.R. 2052, to amend the Uniform Code of Military Justice to prohibit the wrongful broadcast or distribution of intimate visual images, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 418 yeas with none voting ``nay'', Roll No. 277; and

extension.searchTitle: VA SCHEDULING ACCOUNTABILITY ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the bill was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measures. Consideration began Tuesday, May 23rd.<P/>H.R. 467, to direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to ensure that each medical facility of the Department of Veterans Affairs complies with requirements relating to scheduling veterans for health care appointments, and to improve the uniform application of directives of the Department, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 419 yeas with none voting ``nay'', Roll No. 278.

extension.searchTitle: REDUCING REGULATORY BURDENS ACT OF 2017; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.result: So the motion to recommit was rejected.

congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 953, to amend the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act and the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to clarify Congressional intent regarding the regulation of the use of pesticides in or near navigable waters, by a recorded vote of 256 ayes to 165 noes, Roll No. 282.

congVote.result: The PRESIDING OFFICER. Under the previous order, the motion to reconsider is considered made and laid upon the table, and the President will be immediately notified of the Senate's action.

extension.searchTitle: CLOTURE MOTION; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 90

congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Securing our Agriculture and Food Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: <P/>Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs was discharged from further consideration of H.R. 1238, to amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to make the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security for Health Affairs responsible for coordinating the efforts of the Department of Homeland Security related to food, agriculture, and veterinary defense against terrorism, and the bill was then passed, after agreeing to the following amendment proposed thereto:<P/>Sullivan (for Roberts/McCaskill) Amendment No. 217, to preserve the authority of the Secretaries of Agriculture and Health and Human Services and make a technical correction.<P/>: Senate resumed consideration of the nomination of Amul R. Thapar, of Kentucky, to be United States Circuit Judge for the Sixth Circuit.<P/>During consideration of this nomination today, Senate also took the following action:<P/>By 52 yeas to 48 nays (Vote No. 136), Senate agreed to the motion to close further debate on the nomination.
